summary: This video provides an instructional guide to the unique aspects and secrets of starting a DC-3 aircraft, featuring pilot Dan Gryder and co-pilot Russ Still, as they explain and demonstrate the engine start-up process.

events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker confirming good engine operation, followed by another male speaker agreeing, indicating normal engine behavior. He mentions the need for avionics for the video demonstration. The first speaker then asks about starting engine number two. The second man affirms this and instructs on avionics. There's a sound of machinery starting, and the second man gives instructions, confirming a boost pump and pre-oiler. He then directs the first man to look out the window for clearance. The second continues describing the pre-oiling and spinning of the engine, commenting on its speed. Instructions follow for turning off the pre-oiler and activating the mixture and mags, succeeded by an engine start sound. The second speaker says, "Woohoo!" This is followed by the direction to turn the avionics on. There is brief agreement. It starts smoothly with "a nice belch of smoke," and they transition to ship power with the batteries now charging. To end, they mention running through the after-start checklist and pre-taxi checklist.

events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with speech. One male speaker outlines starting DC3 planes and the ease of starting up the engine. They state that it is a "crazy thing where you need all your fingers and your toes to start one of these big radials". The second male speaker agrees and states that they let the engine idle at about 7 to 750 RPM for a while. The first male speaker thanks the audience for tuning in.
